5. Let $D$ be the set of real numbers excluding -1 . Find all functions $f: D \rightarrow D$ such that for all $x, y \in D$ satisfying $x \neq 0$ and $y \neq-x$, the equality

$$
(f(f(x))+y) f\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)+f(f(y))=x
$$

holds.

Solution: Plugging in $x=y \neq 0$ yields $f(f(x))=\alpha x$ for some constant $\alpha$. This holds for all $x \neq 0,-1$. If $\alpha$ was any real number different from 0 or 1 , we would get $f(f(-1 / \alpha))=-1$, which is a contradiction. Hence, only $\alpha=0$ or $\alpha=1$ are possible. In the former case $x=1, y=0$ gives a contradiction, so $f(f(x))=x$ for all $x \in D, x \neq 0$. Letting $x=1, y=f(1)$ gives $f(1)=0$ and so $f(0)=1$. Now, for all other $x$, we can plug in $\frac{1}{x}$ instead of $x$ and $y=1$ to obtain $f(x)=\frac{1-x}{1+x}$ (this formula now also works for $x=0$ ), and we can verify that this is indeed a solution:

$$
f(f(x))=\frac{1-\frac{1-x}{1+x}}{1+\frac{1-x}{1+x}}=\frac{1-x-(1-x)}{1+x+1-x}=x
$$

and thus

$$
(f(f(x))+y) f\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)+f(f(y))=(x+y) f\left(\frac{y}{x}\right)+y=(x+y) \frac{1-\frac{y}{x}}{1+\frac{y}{x}}+y=x-y+y=x
$$

Using two methods to calculate a quantity once each, and constructing an equation from the identical results, is known as the "calculate twice" method. By utilizing this method, combined with the binomial theorem, many interesting combinatorial identities can be derived.

For example, consider the identity $(1+x)^{2n}=(1+x)^{n}(1+x)^{n}(n\in N^{*})$, the coefficient of $x^{n}$ on the left side is $C_{2n}^{n}$. On the right side, $(1+x)^{n}(1+x)^{n}=(C_{n}^{0}+C_{n}^{1}x+\ldots+C_{n}^{n}x^{n})(C_{n}^{0}+C_{n}^{1}x+\ldots+C_{n}^{n}x^{n})$,

the coefficient of $x^{n}$ is $C_{n}^{0}C_{n}^{n}+C_{n}^{1}C_{n}^{n-1}+\ldots+C_{n}^{n}C_{n}^{0}=(C_{n}^{0})^{2}+(C_{n}^{1})^{2}+\ldots+(C_{n}^{n})^{2}$, therefore, we can obtain the combinatorial identity $C_{2n}^{n}=(C_{n}^{0})^{2}+(C_{n}^{1})^{2}+\ldots+(C_{n}^{n})^{2}$.
